[7918569]
Kompera

How "polished" should an entry be before posting it to the wiki?

I've got a page to add from my personal notes (and now, also from wiki diving), but I don't know everything about the subject so I've got a few questions interspersed amongst the information.

Submit whatever you have, it's always better than having nothing! The polishing can be done later, either by you or others (such as myself).
____________________________________________________________

I've spent a bunch of time today working on various technicalities to polish our wiki and make it more uniform, introducing several Templates which I'd advise everyone to use in their articles.

For starters, I've introduced templates for Characters, Skills, AP, MP, Morale and Glory. You can now use the following code to mention these things in your articles:

{{Character|Char name|long}} - http://mushpedia.com/wiki/Template:Character
Displays a character's name with their icon. (optional: displays the full name)
Example:
{{Character|Chun}}
->
Chun

{{Skill|Skill name|size}} - http://mushpedia.com/wiki/Template:Skill
Displays a skill, its respective icon and links to the respective article. (optional: change icon size)
Example:
{{Skill|Shooter}}
->
<icon> Shooter

{{AP|type}} - http://mushpedia.com/wiki/Template:AP
Displays an AP icon and name of the point. (Optional: Skill-specific AP types)
Examples:
3 {{AP|repair}}s
5 {{AP|IT}}s
->
3 Repair points
5 IT points

{{MP}} - [http://mushpedia.com/wiki/Template:MP
Displays the MP icon and MP text.
Example: 3 {{MP}}

{{Glory|mush}} - http://mushpedia.com/wiki/Template:Glory
Displays a Glory icon and Glory text. (optional parameter uses Mush icon)

Examples:
8 {{Glory}}
3 {{Glory|mush}}
->
8 Glory
3 Glory

{{Morale}} - http://mushpedia.com/wiki/Template:Morale
Displays a Morale icon and the 'Morale' text.

Example:
3 {{Morale}}
->
3 Morale
____________________________________________________________

The template links contain more information on what the templates do and how to use them. (The Mush forum breaks the links, so copy them into your browser manually)

For an example, a page where I've used the templates is the Dirty article.

I hope this will make editing more fun, as you now only need to write "3 {{AP}}" instead of "3 [[Image:pa slot1.png|link=Player Resources#Action Points]] AP" to display AP with a neat icon and hyperlink, and it takes much less effort to write "{{Character|Frieda|long}}" to get a nice link with an icon rather than typing up "[[Image:Frieda_icon.png|link=Frieda Bergmann]] [[Frieda Bergmann]]", which I'm sure most couldn't be bothered to do. Now you can easily write polished-looking articles without worrying too much!

Bunch of stuff happened today! Besides the new templates we've also updated the front page with some changed-up sections, renamed a bunch of articles and, among others, expanded the following ones:

After an unnecessary amount of work I've finished up a new Skills system that will replace the need to type and, later, update the same skill description text across 4 or 5 different articles, now instead drawing all information directly from the skill page. However, to kickstart this system, the existing Skill pages need to be converted to a new format.... and that's where your (wo)manpower comes in!

Once the skills are all converted I will finish up the Skills list page and then work on getting the info into the character pages.

You can easily find images uploaded to wiki here: http://mushpedia.com/wiki/Image_Gallery

I believe ivy shows basics here on forums, but I will refresh:

[[Pagename]] -> Pagename - leads to Pagename
[[Pagename|Linkname]] -> Linkname - leads to Pagename
[[Pagename#subthread|Linkname]] - Linkname - leads to Pagename subthread

These are basics, you should be able to add simple data to wiki with this.

In-game description of Chun's level 4 and level 5 skills:
http://tinypic.com/r/35c54iw/5

How lethargy looks like:
http://oi41.tinypic.com/2dcbjhy.jpg

Corresponding ap slot is shaded in blue when her ap passes 12+. For example, first ap slot is shaded in blue if she has 13 ap.
In-game description is misleading; she earns the extra ap for the fourth and each consecutive cycle she's in bed before that cycle ends. It doesn't matter if she gets up to do other activities. As long as she's in bed before cycle end, she will still receive the ap bonus.

I've never used sneak in action, so I can't verify if it works as intended.

Concerning two distinctions :

was a one-time distinction given to French players a year ago after a series of serious bugs affected all ships. justlikethat
spacekadtHow about something constructive instead of just snarking?

It is all tone in tone. You can't identify hyperlinks with one glance. People want to skim pages, not read through the whole page to find the content they are interested in.
This isn't only me or my personal like or dislike. Google "best colors readability", and you'll read over and over again that dark colors on a light background, or indeed black on white is the best in terms of readability. This is from one of the links:
Contrast is the core factor in whether or not text is easy to read. Good contrasts will make text easy on the eyes, easy to scan quickly, and overall more readable. On the other hand, poor contrast will force the user to squint and make reading the body text almost painful, not to mention a lot slower.
As shown in the following illustration, black on white is very readable. Black on white is obviously the standard contrast colors, and to achieve readable content it is good to stay in the range of black-on-white contrast. 10 Principles For Readable Web Typography
Also a good article with links where you can test readability/contrast.
A Guide To Improve Your Website’s Readability Through Colors
But hey, good looking out for them in the name of masking your dislike!
Or, just maybe I'm giving a lot of presentations where I want people to be able to easily see what I'm showing them, so I think about readability a lot, including whether or not something is readable for colorblind or visually impaired people.

[7950824]

I've actually never edited a wiki page ever, anywhere.... and I'm actually not even sure how to. I suppose there's a wiki page somewhere to tell you how to edit wiki pages?
On march 17, 2014
[7918569]

Yup!

Basically, you just sign up for a Mushpedia account, which enables the "edit" button at the top of each page.

The most basic 'wiki markup' (ways to format text, make it bold, italic, put it in lists, etc) can be found here:

http://www.mediawiki.org/wiki/Help:Fo...

A more in-depth guide to more advanced and clean formatting can be found here:

http://meta.wikimedia.org/wiki/Help:A...

As for Mushpedia-specific things, I've tried to lay down a couple of rules and helpful guidelines here.

http://mushpedia.com/wiki/Help:Editin...

The usage of templates (pre-made bits of code that make it easier to display some things, i.e. items, skills and characters with their respective icons, and special things like AP and MP) is also explained here:

http://mushpedia.com/wiki/Category:Us...

4 links may sound like a ton of reading, but they actually aren't. Most of this is really straightforward and you'd probably only have to refer to these help articles once in a blue moon. Give it a try!

Remember that, even if your edit shouldn't be perfect, there's always other users to help, clean and adapt your edit, as long as it's fundamentally productive.

On march 17, 2014
[7918569]

Some basic info on fires should be found in the Fires section of the Dangers page. As for which items get broken and which ones don't, right now you can navigate to every item's respective article and check the List of attributes (example). If the item is fully destroyed, it will say so; same goes for whether or not it is just "broken".

A rule of thumb is that any item which can be repaired will also be broken by fires. Those without repair chances will likely be fully destroyed, such as consumables, books etc.

I will add more item categories later, which will allow sorting items by function and property easier. I'll likely add "Destroyed in Fire" and "Breakable" categories, for example. Until then, just check the item pages you need!

//EDIT:// actually adding these categories right now; they should be populated in a short while.

On march 17, 2014
Secondary

I belive most of those dont get destroyed or broken, some might not be known too though so be careful.
On march 17, 2014
[7918569]
ImpetAny idea about them items that are not attributed as broken or destroyed? Such as Space Capsule?

Well; either they don't break, or the wiki lacks information on those! You will generally know the difference by opening the article source and checking if a field like "Is Destroyed in Fire" is left blank in the item attributes. If it is, someone's probably waiting for confirmation on whether or not this item is consumed in fire. If it's entirely missing, the field in question does not apply to the item. (i.e. it's not destroyed in fire).

Mind that the item articles are a very recent development (a few weeks old), and there haven't been a lot of contributions yet.

[8281990]

Based on observed game behavior, the identities of the Mush are probably chosen randomly when the ship is created. It then comes down to whether you picked one of the people who will "awaken" when the ship fills. Effectively it's still random in the same way, the difference is that if someone who was meant to be mush dies before selection (usually via quarantine), the dead person will be revealed as mush instead of it picking from the players who are still alive. Pre-selection deaths are rare though, so you won't see this often.

To be quarantined, you must be banned from playing mush while on a ship. When one is quarantined, you are immediately killed and will drop several items. Something about waste. As far as I know, there is one case in the entire history of mush where someone has been quarantined on the same ship in which they took the action they were quarantined for.

On february 13, 2016
[8744424]

Vince, apparently, you've misunderstood my position, so I'll try to give a better explanation.


As for withholding information from people so they can "figure it out" themselves... I do not believe in that. That was nothing close to what I stated. What I did state was that factual data should be separated from the info about strategies. Separated, not withheld.
~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~

Firstly, for the already mentioned ideological reason. I'm pretty sure most of the players would be disappinted, if, while exploring the basic information about what the game is about and what the controls and hot keys are, they bump into "to defeat the main boss you can just hit their face with a bucket filled with potatoes - and voila''.

And my opinion is that step-to-step kind of tactics and guides, situational and (or) detailed tactics should be stored on sources other than mushpedia with mushpedia, providing links to them (e.g. making a "Possible Strategies" page with a classification of those, linking to articles with guides, like: Level 1.Human strategies L2. Mush strategies. L1.1. strategy for character_1 L1.2. strategy for character_2.... and then links themselves, attached to short descriptions of specific strategies they're leading to). That wouldn't make users think that those are only possible or strongly recommended ways of playing, since it's clear that those are opinions or suggestions of other players, just like themselves.
Making a new section in mushpedia and adding them their is also an option, and it's benefit is - ease of maintaining the data and keeping it up-to-date. And verifying it doesn't contain false info. But in this case they should be presented in a suggestive way ("possible strategies", "strategy ideas" and such) and phrased carefully and neutrally ("this is probably the best tactics" shouldn't be the way to go with). And being enough detailed and provided with warnings, if those are needed, not to misguide players.
~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~

Secondly, - for a logical reason - to make data bearable for information perceiving and for easier navigation and search. Wiki is a tool for structuring data, after all. What types of wins does the game offer is a one thing and how to achieve those wins is another (all that is pretty much about the Aim of the Game page).

In fact, the strategies already were all over the "Aim of the Game" page. Those were not strategies, but requirements for a win, the description of what is counted as a win, since for this game it's not obvious. Strategies, in this case, would be possible ways of achieving those wins (e.g. aim = infiltrate sol/eden; strategie = mimic or force the return -> force the return by trading crewmate for pilgred)
~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~

About the Skills Page and adding tips for mushplay for cahracters.

Human sections always had tips only, while same can't be said about mush (and welp, human characters don't have any specific mission to give tactics advice about, except for, maybe, suggestions on how to gain trust withing others as a human, or what plan to chose as this particular character in case of a rampage or smth like that (I do have those for my characters usually, for example) ).

Human skills are more about game mechanics. What combinations are optimal, how skills are alligned with the character's role. I'd, though, added that most of the skill choisees are situational and it's better to wait with some of them to figure out which will fit better for the ship. And also some tips about those situations, maybe, and such.

[8281990]

In some places the issue is just the language on the page. The problem that I had with Mush Frieda's tips in particular were not what the tips were (they are accurate in that Frieda has to lie low if she doesn't immediately act, and planets are a unique way she can screw over the crew), but that they are written in a way that sounds more like "this is how you do it" than "these are available options."

It's a subtle difference, and one that I aim to improve as I can snatch bits of editing time. The reason I think it's important is I don't want newbies to automatically follow all the tips given as if it's a walkthrough. Mush play is very situation-dependent and the language of the tips need to make that abundantly clear, in my opinion.

Which is why, outside of a few pointers on the character pages (which I do think is a good idea!), I agree that strategy suggestions are best on independent pages. Covering all your bases at once will likely make for a lot of writing, which can bury the simple reference material on a given page if you're not careful. Or make the page into an intimidating (for newbies) wall of text.

Ok, I'm gonna see if sickbrain will cooperate with me here.

Mushpedia is a *community* resource, maintained *by the community*. As long as you're not messing around with the templates and overall structure of the wiki, I think everything has its place.

Long, drawn out strategies should go in appropriate places (generally a page devoted to such), but simple things like "here's a good way to start thinking of playing this character as a mush" very much does have its place on the character's page. On april 10, 2017
SummerMcLovin

I was asked this via PM now that this ship is over, but just in case someone is still editing Mushpedia, I can answer the "Do Mush get Sepsis?" question.

Technically yes, the game does try to give the Mush the Sepsis disease and they receive a private log to that effect. However, this does not appear as a status so couldn't be cured via healing, nor does it take effect over cycle change.
As there is only a private log, there is no way to confuse other players that you are human. The only way someone else would be able to see this is if you Transferred into their old body, which should leave them with little doubt that you are a Mush.
On april 10, 2017
wLink

I've dicussed it with some other people few months ago and it seems quite possible that for mushes "succumbed to geralised infection" death seems to be caused by injuries that kill you once you get dirty rather than sepsis itself.
On april 10, 2017
[8281990]

I've seen this myself, yes. Sepsis the disease (the one received from a failed surgery) cannot be caught by mush. Sepsis the cause-of-death is from injuries that kill you when you get dirty (or if already dirty, the next cycle change.) Both mush and humans are susceptible to the latter.

On september 1, 2018
nick

I was able to hit 0 morale and not die on a ship. Screen shotted it. Is that a known bug?
On september 1, 2018
Chime

It's only a bug if you survived a cycle change with 0 moral. There is a certain order to things. You commit suicide when you have 0 moral on cycle change so even if you hit zero for example by getting demoralized you have the rest of the cycle to fix your moral.
On september 1, 2018
Shadowghost

Also, panic attacks happen after the moral check (in which if you have 0 moral you commit suicide), so if you have 1, 2, or 3 moral on cycle change and lose them due to panic attack, you won't die until the next cycle change.
